GREEK 1.title: Elementary Greek
GREEK 1.description: The beginning course in classical Greek and first in a three-quarter sequence introducing fundamentals of grammar, syntax, and reading skills. Concepts taught using written exercises. Interesting aspects of Ancient Greek society are introduced.

GREEK 2.title: Elementary Greek
GREEK 2.prereq_description: Greek 1 with a grade of C or better.
GREEK 2.description: A continuation of Greek 1. Emphasis on mastering grammar and building vocabulary.

GREEK 3.title: Intermediate Greek
GREEK 3.prereq_description: Greek 2 with a grade of C or better.
GREEK 3.description: A continuation of Greek 2. Emphasis on building a working vocabulary and the syntax of complex sentences. Readings in classical prose introduce students to ancient Greek literature and culture.

GREEK 10A.title: Elementary Modern Greek
GREEK 10A.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has alreadybeen awarded.
GREEK 10A.description: First in a two quarter sequence, this course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Greek language, but are keen to learn basic Greek reading, writing and conversation. Also introduces students to contemporary Greek culture.

GREEK 10B.title: Intermediate Modern Greek
GREEK 10B.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has alreadybeen awarded.
GREEK 10B.description: Second in a two quarter sequence, this course moves toward a greater command of conversation and reading comprehension. Audio-visual materials aid language acquisition and enrich the understanding of Greek culture and history.

GREEK 12SS.title: Intensive Elementary Ancient Greek
GREEK 12SS.description: An intensive course in elementary ancient Greek language, only taught in summer in a 6 week session. New grammar and vocabulary is introduced every day, so daily class attendance and participation are essential.  No prior experience with learning a foreign language is required or assumed.

GREEK 100.title: Introduction To Greek Prose
GREEK 100.prereq_description: Greek 3 with a grade of C or better.
GREEK 100.description: Reading and analysis of attic prose writers such as Xenophon and Plato to develop reading skills and introduce study of the style and thought of historical, rhetorical and/or philosophical writers.

GREEK 101.title: Introduction To Greek Poetry
GREEK 101.prereq_description: Greek 100 with a grade of C or better.
GREEK 101.description: Reading in the poetry of Homer to develop reading skills, introduce Homeric grammar and meter, and begin study of the style, thought and heroic world of epic poetry.

GREEK 102.title: Readings In Greek Literature
GREEK 102.description: Selected reading in Greek prose and/or poetry designed to develop reading proficiency, and to help students make the transition to more advanced study of classical Greek literature.

GREEK 110.title: Attic Orators
GREEK 110.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Greek 108 to a maximum of 8 units with consent of instructor.
GREEK 110.description: Reading and study of attic orators such as Demosthenes, and of famous orations by Demosthenes and other attic orators.

GREEK 120.title: Greek Novel
GREEK 120.description: Advanced reading and study of selected chapters of an ancient Greek novel, with attention to the language and style of the work and to its literary, social and political contexts.

GREEK 125.title: Greek Biography
GREEK 125.description: Advanced reading and study of selections from Greek texts that focus on the 'lives' of notable figures (such as Xenophon's Cyropaedia, Plutarch's Lives, and the Life of Aesop). Attention is paid to the language and style of the works, as well to the genre of 'biography'.

GREEK 138.title: Pre-Socratic Philosophers
GREEK 138.description: Readings in the first "formal" philosophers of the Western tradition. Normally includes all of the major pre-Socratics (Parmenides, Heraclitus, Pythagoras, Xenophanes, Anaxagoras, Democritus) and their contributions to European thought. Sometimes concentrates upon thinkers of the fifth- century Sophistic Movement.

GREEK 142.title: Plato
GREEK 142.description: Reading of one or several Platonic dialogues from the early or middle period (Laches, Protagoras, Phaedo, Gorgias, Symposium), both as masterpieces of Greek literature and as philosophical dialogues. No prior formal training in philosophy is required.

GREEK 143.title: Post-Platonic Philosophers
GREEK 143.description: Readings of selections from the more famous works of Aristotle (Nicomachean Ethics, Politics, De Anima, Metaphysics), emphasizing Aristotle both as thinker and as stylist; occasionally excerpts from Theophrastus, the Stoics, Plotinus. No prior formal training in philosophy required.

GREEK 151.title: Euripides
GREEK 151.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Euripides, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama.

GREEK 152.title: Sophocles
GREEK 152.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Sophocles, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama.

GREEK 153.title: Aeschylus
GREEK 153.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Aeschylus, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama.

GREEK 154.title: Aristophanes
GREEK 154.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of a complete comedy of Aristophanes, with attention to language, meter, staging, comic themes and conventions, and the social and cultural context of Athenian drama.

GREEK 158.title: Homer
GREEK 158.description: Reading and study of selections from the Illiad and/or Odyssey.

GREEK 161.title: Hesiod, Theognis, And Solon
GREEK 161.description: Reading and study of Archaic poets.

GREEK 162.title: Herodotus
GREEK 162.description: Reading and study of the histories of Herodotus.

GREEK 171.title: Lyric Poets And Homeric Hymns
GREEK 171.description: Reading and study of lyric poets and Homeric hymns.

GREEK 173.title: Hellenistic Poets
GREEK 173.description: Introduction to the poetry of the Alexandrian period, normally concentrating upon a single major poet such as Apollonius Rhodius, Callimachus, or Theocritus. Reading, translation, and discussion, with attention to language, meter, generic innovation, cultural context, and formative influence upon Latin literature.

GREEK 199.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and department chair; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Greek.
GREEK 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
GREEK 199.description: Independent investigations in Greek language and literature.

GREEK 210.title: Attic Orators
GREEK 210.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Greek 208 to a maximum of 12units.
GREEK 210.description: Advanced reading and study of Attic orators such as Demosthenes, Lysias, Aeschines, and Isocrates, with attention to the language, style, and rhetoric of the speeches, and to their political and historical context.

GREEK 220.title: Greek Novel
GREEK 220.description: Advanced reading and study of selected chapters of an ancient Greek novel, with attention to the language and style of the work and to its literary, social and political contexts.

GREEK 225.title: Greek Biography
GREEK 225.description: Advanced reading and study of selections from Greek texts that focus on the 'lives' of notable figures (such as Xenophon's Cyropaedia, Plutarch's Lives, and the Life of Aesop). Attention is paid to the language and style of the works, as well to the genre of 'biography'.

GREEK 238.title: Pre-Socratic Philosophers
GREEK 238.description: Advanced readings in the first "formal" philosophers of the Western tradition. Normally includes all the major pre-Socratics (Parmenides, Heraclitus, Pythagoras, Xenophones, Anaxagoras, Democritus) and their contributions to European thought. Sometimes concentrates upon thinkers of the fifth-century Sophistic Movement.

GREEK 240.title: Greek Prose Composition
GREEK 240.description: Improves active knowledge of the Greek language, both grammar and vocabulary, through careful writing. Refines a feeling for the Greek employed in various genres of Greek literature. Demonstrates how a feel for style helps interpret and explicate Greek literature.

GREEK 242.title: Plato
GREEK 242.description: Advanced reading of one or several Platonic dialogues from the early or middle period (Laches, Protagoras, Phaedo, Gorgias, Symposium), both as masterpieces of Greek literature and as philosophical dialogues.

GREEK 243.title: Post-Platonic Philosophers
GREEK 243.description: Advanced reading of selections from the more famous works of Aristotle (Nicomachean Ethics, Politics, De Anima, Metaphysics), emphasizing Aristotle both as thinker and as stylist; occasionally excerpts from Theophrastus, the Stoics, Plotinus.

GREEK 251.title: Euripides
GREEK 251.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 251.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Euripides, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama, with an introduction to current scholarship.

GREEK 252.title: Sophocles
GREEK 252.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 252.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Sophocles, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama, with an introduction to current scholarship.

GREEK 253.title: Aeschylus
GREEK 253.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 253.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of a complete tragedy of Aeschylus, with attention to language, meter, staging, tragic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama, with an introduction to current scholarship.

GREEK 254.title: Aristophanes
GREEK 254.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 254.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of a complete comedy of Aristophanes, with attention to language, meter, staging, comic themes and conventions, and the cultural context of Athenian drama, with an introduction to current scholarship.

GREEK 258.title: Homer
GREEK 258.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
GREEK 258.description: Advanced reading and study of selections from the Iliad and/or Odyssey.

GREEK 261.title: Hesiod, Theognis, and Solon
GREEK 261.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
GREEK 261.description: Advanced reading and study in the archaic poets.

GREEK 262.title: Herodotus
GREEK 262.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
GREEK 262.description: Advanced reading and study in the histories of Herodotus.

GREEK 263.title: Thucydides
GREEK 263.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 263.description: Advanced reading and research in the historical, literary, and philological aspects of Thucydides.

GREEK 271.title: Lyric Poets and Homeric Hymns
GREEK 271.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
GREEK 271.description: Advanced reading and study of lyric poems and Homeric hymns.

GREEK 272.title: Pindar
GREEK 272.comments: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 272.description: Advanced reading, interpretation, metrical study, and textual criticism. Introduction to other choral poets.

GREEK 273.title: Hellenistic Poets
GREEK 273.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
GREEK 273.description: Advanced study in poetry of the Alexandrian period, normally concentrating upon a single major poet such as Apollonius, Callimachus, or Theocritus, with attention to language, meter, generic innovation, cultural context, and formative influence upon Latin literature. Includes introduction to current scholarship.

GREEK 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
GREEK 596.prereq_description: Written proposal approved by department chair and graduate advisor.

GREEK 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
GREEK 598.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor and graduate advisor.
GREEK 598.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
